author: Mirage News
title: Starting Dialogue On Rare Disease In South Carolina | Mirage News
text: [The South Carolina Rare Disease Advocacy Council](https://rarediseasesc.org/) (SCRDAC) held its inaugural symposium on Feb. 29 in Columbia to engage researchers, patients and advocates in conversations about how to improve the lives of the state's rare disease community. The first session featured presentations from researchers about clinical trials and genetic testing. The second session consisted of an advocacy panel in which panelists discussed what let them to advocacy and addressed the challenges those with rare diseases face. Although any one rare disease affects a relatively small group of patients, when combined, rare diseases affect more than 30 million people in the U.S. Despite this, diagnoses can be missed by medical professionals, who are trained to look for "horses" (common diseases) and not "zebras" (rare diseases), making the path longer to treatment and a better quality of life for patients. The lack of funding for research into rare diseases reduces the likelihood of breakthrough treatments, and it can also be difficult to recruit enough patients for trials to determine the effectiveness of treatment. Participation by the rare disease community in clinical trials can partly overcome this challenge, according to [Patrick Flume, M.D.](https://providers.muschealth.org/sc/charleston/patrick-a.-flume-md), SCRDAC chair and co-director of the [South Carolina Clinical and Translational Research Institute](https://research.musc.edu/resources/sctr) (SCTR), who kicked off the symposium with opening remarks. As a pulmonologist, cystic fibrosis researcher and one who runs clinical trials, he has seen firsthand how new medications designed specifically for individuals with genetic variations that cause cystic fibrosis have transformed medical care. Not so long ago, it was not unusual for patients with cystic fibrosis to have died in their twenties. Now, thanks to new drugs that target the genetic causes of the disease, they can live into their fifties. If genetic variants responsible for other rare diseases can be determined, then it stands to reason that therapeutic drugs can be developed and tested for them as well. But they will only be identified if patients participate in registries to find the variants and in trials to test potential therapies. Following Flume's presentation, the symposium welcomed Daniel Judge, M.D., a cardiovascular genetics expert at MUSC and a member of the SCRDAC. He introduced [In Our DNA SC](https://web.musc.edu/inourdnasc), an initiative that aims to screen 100,000 South Carolinians, at no cost, for certain mutations known to be highly associated with particular diseases. The program uses Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Tier-1 gene testing for three of the most common rare diseases for which clinical practice guidelines are available. Approximately 80% of rare diseases are genetic, which is why genetic screenings like In Our DNA SC are so important. They help to identify people with specific genetic differences that cause diseases. This can speed up the diagnosis process and provide Genetic screening also took center stage in the presentation by [Neena Champaigne, M.D.](https://providers.muschealth.org/sc/north-charleston/neena-l.-champaigne-md), in which she discussed the importance of newborn screening. Newborn screening saves or improves the lives of over 13,000 babies a year by identifying potentially fatal genetic disorders early, Champagne said. The number of lives saved is expected to increase as screening methods improve and the number of conditions being screened for continues to increase. Champaigne also noted the need for appropriate follow-up and clinical infrastructure to address abnormal results. People who screen positive for genetic mutations associated with various diseases may struggle to understand the results or their implications. That's where genetic counselors like MUSC's [Maysen Mesaros](https://education.musc.edu/MUSCApps/facultydirectory/Mesaros-Maysen) and [Olivia Thompson](https://education.musc.edu/MUSCApps/FacultyDirectory/Thompson-Olivia-) come in. Their presentation emphasized the importance of seeking genetic counseling before and after screening to discuss medical and family histories, screening results and navigation to appropriate care and clinical trials. "Many basic scientists will never know a patient with the disease they are studying. Without that, how can you know the true relevance of your work?" -- Dr. Chip Norris The research session concluded with [Chip Norris, Ph.D.](https://medicine.musc.edu/departments/regenerative-medicine/research/norris-lab), who takes a patient-focused approach to his research on hypermobile Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (hEDS). His journey into hEDS research started when he met then-graduate student [Cortney Gensemer, Ph.D.](https://web.musc.edu/about/news-center/2023/03/21/research-phenom), who has the disease. He was shocked to learn that researchers had not identified the specific genetic variation causing the disease and encouraged Gensemer to make finding the variant the focus of her thesis project. From this experience, Norris learned an important lesson. "Many basic scientists will never know a patient with the disease they are studying," he said. "Without that, how can you know the true relevance of your work?" Norris and Gensemer have been actively working to change this trend by involving patient-scientists in the work of the lab. His lab welcomes individuals with hEDS and other EDS subtypes who are passionate about science and research. Norris also emphasized the importance of a patient registry in identifying genetic variants and how the discovery of a causative variant can expedite the diagnostic process for these patients. Since that initial meeting with Gensemer, Norris and his team have discovered candidate genes for the hypermobile type and validated this finding in an animal model. Day in and day out, they champion the significance of and expansion of patient-focused research. After the research presentations, a rare disease advocacy panel, whose members had personal or family experience with a rare disease, shared their experiences and concerns as well as fielded questions from researchers and attendees. Advocates pointed out that change becomes more likely when people with different rare diseases unify and collaborate with physicians, researchers and policymakers to better the lives of the whole community. They encouraged members of the rare disease community to own their expertise and lived experiences with the disease and to feel more confident in communicating their needs. They said that doing so would help to raise awareness about rare diseases and the challenges faced by this community. The SCRDAC hopes that by starting these conversations, it will lead to continuing collaborations that will ultimately improve the lives and care of the state's rare disease population. The SCRDAC is committed to spearheading efforts to raise awareness of the community's needs and providing assistance to individuals in navigating access to vital resources, essential care and clinical trial opportunities. Related Links To learn more about clinical trials in South Carolina, visit [SCResearch.org](http://scresearch.org/). [here](https://www.miragenews.com/starting-dialogue-on-rare-disease-in-south-1209172/).

title: #31 Marruecos eleva su presupuesto militar hasta los 21.000 millones de euros frente a los 15.000 actuales de Espa√±a

[#9](c9#c-9) Todo eso esta muy bonico, pero por mucho cari√±o que le tengan UsA a Marruecos y les interese sabotear a Argelia hay que tener en cuenta que lo √∫ltimo que querria USA en la zona (y tambi√©n UK y Francia) es que haya pepinos sobrevolando el estrecho de Gibraltar.

[#6](c6#c-6) si EEUU tiene que elegir entre Marruecos y Espa√±a no dudes que elegir√° a Marruecos, pues fue el primer pa√≠s del mundo en reconocer su independencia y esas tonter√≠as a EEUU le molan.
Y ya lo ha demostrado en ver√≠as ocasiones, como por ejemplo en la marcha verde.

[#1](c1#c-1) Tal como esta la cosa aqu√≠, no me extra√±ar√≠a que nos tomen Ceuta,Melilla,las canarias , media pen√≠nsula y nos obliguen a pagarles la factura de la invasi√≥n. Con los pol√≠ticos diciendo que era lo mejor desmantelar el ejercito para no morir gente , que es mejor tener mas dinero para hospitales y colegios . No lo digo de co√±a.
[#1](c1#c-1) No van a atacar la pen√≠nsula, pero esta Ceuta y Melilla, en las cuales no van a hacer un ataque militar, pero cuando quieran las ocupan como en la marcha verde, hace pocos a√±os nos metieron 10.000 civiles en un d√≠a y no hicimos nada, y ah√≠ est√° el problema, que Espa√±a tenga que ir a Marruecos a echarlos, y ya te digo que a d√≠a de hoy no tenemos nada que hacer.
Espa√±a debe poder defender su soberan√≠a, el gasto en defensa de Espa√±a es rid√≠culo, la diplomacia con pa√≠ses como Marruecos se ejerce dando una mano y levantando un palo en la otra, es decir, con disuasi√≥n, pues esa disuasi√≥n la hemos perdido en la √∫ltima d√©cada.
[#1](c1#c-1) 10 mil millones gasta Argelia. C√≥mo bien dices, bien podr√≠an haberlo comparado con ellos.
https://datosmacro.expansion.com/estado/gasto/defensa/argelia
En 2022 Espa√±a gast√≥ 20 mil millones...
https://datosmacro.expansion.com/estado/gasto/defensa/espana
La noticia apesta a sensacionalismo.
[#1](c1#c-1) Pues ojo con tanto gasto, que mayormente se va al bolsillo del t√≠o Sam y este se lo cobra en materias primas del S√°hara que les regal√≥ el campechano.
Probablemente sean ventas con intereses para poder exprimirles todav√≠a m√°s y el d√≠a de ma√±ana se lo quieran cobrar en carne, como hicieron en Espa√±a con el cicl√°n, metiendo bases americanas en el pais. Y ni cotiza que van a estar pegadas a Ceuta, Melilla y las Canarias por la posici√≥n estrat√©gica de las primeras y los recursos de las segundas.
¬øPor que cuando salen estas noticias casi todos piensan en Espa√±a?
Amos a ver, existe una cosa que se llama "Alqaeda del Magreb" que opera al sur de Marruecos. Varios paises vecinos a Marruecos han sufrido golpes militares recientes. La situaci√≥n en la zona es bastante inestable, pero por la frontera sur, no por nosotros.
Cojones, que en 2030, Espa√±a va a celebrar un mundial de futbol con Marruecos y Portugal, ¬øc√≥mo van a pensar siguiera en atacarnos?
La Raz√≥n y sus cuentos asustaviejas.
No se a que co√±o viene la comparaci√≥n con Espa√±a, m√°s all√° de la c√°mara de eco para sus avispados lectores y seguir el relato de la ultraderecha del "peligro moro".
Para los m√°s preocupados por tal amenaza solo decirles que se tranquilicen. Espa√±a no es que sea superior militarmente a Marruecos, es que est√° varios √≥rdenes de magnitud por encima. Y esto sin contar con la cooperaci√≥n de la OTAN para un posible conflicto militar que no necesitar√≠a para nada. Argelia mismo es mucho m√°s fuerte que Marruecos. Dejemos de fliparnos con una amenaza inexistente.
Y para los flipaos de "Estados Unidos apoyar√≠a a Marruecos porque nininini..." No. En ning√∫n escenario habido o por haber nadie, repito, nadie va a apoyar a Marruecos, un pa√≠s en v√≠as de desarrollo y pobre de solemnidad en un conflicto con un pa√≠s de la OTAN o de la Uni√≥n Europea mucho, mucho m√°s poderoso militarmente. Ni alianza m√°s antigua ni leches en vinagre. Ni Ceuta y Melilla est√°n bajo el paraguas de OTAN ninini.... No. Si Marruecos atacara Ceuta y Melilla, que nunca lo har√°, ser√≠a el fin del satrapa parisino y vive demasiado bien como para dejar esa vidorra de lujo y musculosos acompa√±antes.
Todo lo que hace Marruecos con estas mierdas son √∫nica y exclusivamente para consumo interno, y cuanto antes entendamos esto y nos dejemos de cuentos para asustar a viejas y seguir el relato de odio racista y xen√≥fobo de la extrema derecha, mucho mejor.
Yo bajaba el presupuesto militar a cero, lo dedicaba a educaci√≥n y empezaba a tener empresas que dominaran paises... caso resuelto.
P.D: Vamos lo que hace EEUU unido a ser el pais que m√°s destina a armamento. Realmente este pa√≠s es decididamente host√≠l lo mires por donde lo mires.
O sea que comparamos el presupuesto de 2025 de Marruecos con lo ejecutado de enero a agosto de 2024 de Espa√±a. Se√±ores de La Raz√≥n: ¬øy por qu√© no comparar el presupuesto de Marruecos en los a√±os 2025 a 2030 con lo ejecutado en Espa√±a en la segunda quincena de abril de 2024? Ya puestos...
No tienen para comer, tienen que escapar en patera, y se gastan m√°s dinero que nosotros en armamento.

author: SBT
title: Gasolina caseira: tentativa de economizar pode gerar preju√≠zos, alerta especialista
text:
Gasolina caseira: tentativa de economizar pode gerar preju√≠zos, alerta especialista
"Receita milagrosa" indica a mistura de gasolina com √≥leo de cozinha viralizou nas redes sociais, mas pode causar danos ao motor do ve√≠culo
Nathalia Fruet
Com a alta nos pre√ßos dos combust√≠veis, uma "receita caseira pra fazer gasolina" em casa para economizar circulou nas redes sociais, mas especialistas alertam: isso √© uma farsa e pode causar um baita preju√≠zo.
O valor m√©dio do litro da gasolina no pa√≠s - segundo a Ag√™ncia Nacional do Petr√≥leo (ANP) - est√° em R$ 6,37. Em um ano, a alta foi de 10,5%. Depois do √∫ltimo reajuste, em janeiro, as "receitas milagrosas" voltaram a viralizar.
Uma das receitas indica a mistura de gasolina com √≥leo de cozinha. "A cada litro de gasolina, voc√™ coloca meio litro de √≥leo", indicam v√≠deos que circulam nas redes sociais.
+ Lula diz que conversar√° com atacadistas sobre pre√ßo do ovo: "Absurdo‚Äù
+ Representantes de bares e restaurantes pedem a Haddad regulamenta√ß√£o do vale-refei√ß√£o
Mas, o barato pode sair caro. Quem acha que isso √© uma alternativa para economizar com a alta dos combust√≠veis, pode acabar gastando ainda mais na oficina
Renato Romil, engenheiro mec√¢nico e gerente do laborat√≥rio de motores do Instituto Mau√° de Tecnologia, explica que o √≥leo, al√©m de n√£o funcionar como combust√≠vel para o carro, causa riscos.
"Essa gasolina misturada com √≥leo de soja vai causar dep√≥sitos dentro do motor, e esses dep√≥sitos v√£o come√ßar a emperrar o funcionamento dos componentes, ent√£o depois de um determinado tempo voc√™ vai ser obrigado a desmontar o motor inteiro, ou parte desse motor, pra poder limpar as pe√ßas que v√£o ser impregnadas", diz o especialista.
E para fazer reparos no motor, prepare o bolso. "Hoje, pra fazer um motor por conta de combust√≠vel adulterado, a pessoa gasta em torno de R$ 8 mil, R$ 9 mil, mais ou menos", explica o mec√¢nico Eduardo Pereira.
Outro ponto √© que o combust√≠vel -- para ser usado -- precisa ter autoriza√ß√£o da ANP.
"Depois pode ter um problema e o seguro negar porque vc adulterou o combustivel pra poder burlar o preco da gasolina", diz o engenheiro Reinaldo Santos.

author: ansa.it
title: Talkdesk accoglie Munil Shah, innovatore nei settori dell‚Äôautomazione cloud e dell‚Äôintelligenza artificiale, come direttore tecnico - Business Wire - Ansa.it
text:
Talkdesk¬Æ, Inc. una delle principali imprese internazionali nel settore dei call center di aziende di tutte le dimensioni che utilizzano l‚ÄôIA, oggi ha annunciato di avere scelto Munil Shah come nuovo direttore tecnico (CTO), rafforzando cos√¨ la propria posizione di leadership come impresa innovatrice nei settori dell‚Äôintelligenza artificiale (IA) e dell‚Äôesperienza del cliente (CX).
Il testo originale del presente annuncio, redatto nella lingua di partenza, √® la versione ufficiale che fa fede. Le traduzioni sono offerte unicamente per comodit√† del lettore e devono rinviare al testo in lingua originale, che √® l'unico giuridicamente valido.

Rimasero insieme 20 mesi e una volta promossi vice brigadieri furono destinati in territori diversi. Si sono ritrovati nei giorni scorsi a Montese. author: MENAFN
title: Indian defense minister tells China that ‚ÄòIndia will not bow down‚Äô | MENAFN.COM
text:
( MENAFN ) In a resolute assertion of its stance amidst ongoing discussions with China over border issues, India's Defense Minister, Rajnath Singh, has emphasized that the nation will not compromise its sovereignty. Singh's remarks come amidst talks with Beijing aimed at resolving disputes along the shared Himalayan border, a region that has witnessed tensions and sporadic clashes in recent years.
Addressing a political rally in Gujarat state, Singh underscored India's commitment to maintaining amicable relations with its neighbors while highlighting the country's bolstered military capabilities. With arms exports soaring to approximately USD2.63 billion in the last fiscal year, representing a substantial growth of 32.5 percent, Singh emphasized India's transformation into a formidable force on the global stage.
Despite the backdrop of strained ties with Beijing due to recurrent skirmishes along the disputed border, Singh conveyed optimism regarding the ongoing dialogue, characterizing the environment as conducive for constructive engagement. However, he affirmed India's steadfastness, asserting that the nation has not yielded to external pressures and remains unwavering in its defense of territorial integrity.
Singh's remarks echo sentiments expressed by Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who recently emphasized the urgency of addressing border disputes and rectifying abnormalities in bilateral relations with China. The tense standoff in the Galwan Valley in June 2020, which resulted in casualties on both sides, served as a stark reminder of the volatility inherent in the border region. While subsequent disengagement efforts have aimed at de-escalating tensions, unresolved friction points persist.
As India and China navigate the complexities of their relationship, marked by geopolitical competition and territorial disputes, the firm assertions from Indian leadership underscore the nation's resolve to safeguard its interests and assert its position on the global stage. Against the backdrop of evolving regional dynamics, the trajectory of Indo-China relations remains subject to ongoing dialogue and strategic maneuvering aimed at fostering stability and mutual cooperation.

author: Staff Writer
title: Senegal's Lions of Teranga have the look of champions - Voice Online
text: SENEGAL qualified for the knockout stages with a game to spare by beating Cameroon 3-1 in Yamoussoukro, leaving the Indominable Lions in a perilous position, reports Vlad Andrejevic. Goals from Ismaila Sarr, Habib Diallo and Sadio Mane proved too much for Cameroon, who will likely need to win their last game against Gambia to have a chance of progressing. It only took a quarter of an hour for the defending champions to go ahead following questionable goalkeeping from the under-fire Andre Onana. As a corner came in, his clearance was unconvincing and fell to Pape Matar Sarr who managed to knock it into Ismaila Sarr‚Äôs path to smash in. Cameroon huffed and puffed in search of an equaliser but were unable to impose themselves on Senegal who seemed to be in cruise control for most of the contest. It was the Lions of Teranga who struck again in the 72nd minute, as the ball fortuitously broke to Ismaila Sarr who fizzed in a brilliant first-time cross into the path of the onrushing Diallo to slide in his first goal of the tournament. Cameroon, who have a reputation of performing best when their backs are against the wall, finally found a breakthrough themselves in the 83rd minute. Substitute Oliver Ntcham produced a wonderful cross which Jean-Charles Castelletto emphatically headed in to give Cameroon hope. They followed it up with two great chances to equalise, both falling to Georges-Kevin N‚ÄôKoudou. Having been inches away from getting on the end of a dangerous cross, he headed wide from inside the six-yard area in stoppage time when it looked easier to score. Senegal‚Äôs veterans responded as Idrissa Gueye, Senegal‚Äôs record cap holder, escaped down the right and found a clever cutback for Senegal‚Äôs record goal-scorer Mane to calmly slot into the corner and put the game to bed.
